dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear the faint sounds of a crowd cheering on Kobe Brya The real Bob Costas does narration.

dialogues.speaker: BOB COSTAS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Before the NBA was the NBA, there was another basketball league in America... DOCUMENTARY FOOTAGE: This is real ABA footage. A series o great plays are made by ABA stars.

dialogues.speaker: BOB COSTAS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: .From 1967 to 1976, there was the American Basketball Association. A maverick minor-league that would change the game forever. The ABA made the fast break FAST... Invented the three point shot... And introduced the world to something called the Slam Dunk Contest. DOCUMENTARY FOOTAGE: Dr. J launches from the foul line an dunks in the world's first dunk contest. David Thompson finishes an Alley Oop.

dialogues.speaker: BOB COSTAS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Singer Pat Boone owned the Oakland Oaks. Wilt Chambelain coached the Conquistadors. I myself was the young voice of the St. Louis Spirits. DOCUMENTARY FOOTAGE: A young Bob Costas broadcasts from S Louis, looking pretty sweet in side burns and a tweed jac

dialogues.speaker: BOB COSTAS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Players like Dr. J, Ice-man George Gervin and Moses Malone were as entertaining as they come. But despite the league's flair, convincing fans to show up for games was often a struggle. DOCUMENTARY FOOTAGE: The infamous TV interview where Fred Lewis wins a 'race horse.' Footage of 'Dime Beer Night.' Footage of the Kentucky Colonials fielding a cheerleader one of their starting five.

dialogues.speaker: BOB COSTAS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: For owners, promotional ideas became an art form all to themselves. DOCUMENTARY FOOTAGE: The Miami Ball Girls dance in bikini (In truth, some of the girls were still in high school).

dialogues.speaker: BOB COSTAS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: One night, the Nets went as far as to give a free gerbil to it's first fifty fans... There were plenty of punches too, giving the National Hockey League a run for it's money. DOCUMENTARY FOOTAGE: A guy elbows Connie Hawkins, who tur and punches the guy in the face.

dialogues.speaker: BOB COSTAS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Yes, the ABA had a style all it's own. The hair was big, the shorts were short and the ball was red, white and blue. DOCUMENTARY FOOTAGE: Harry 'The fat Mexican guy' dances.

dialogues.speaker: BOB COSTAS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: In 1976, rumors of a merger spread throughout the league. In the end, only four teams would join the NBA and survive. QUICK CUTS: THE PACERS. THE NUGGETS. THE NETS. THE SPURS.

dialogues.speaker: BOB COSTAS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Teams like the Kentucky Colonels and the Virginia Squires would disappear forever. But their spirit still lives on to this day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear a crowd going crazy.

dialogues.speaker: BOB COSTAS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Here, we present the legend of the ABA... Exactly as it happened. Some FUNKY MUSIC plays.

dialogues.speaker: BOB COSTAS, (V_O_)
dialogues.text: Except, this Flint Michigan team never existed.
(BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And, well, everything in this movie is completely fake.

dialogues.speaker: TITLE CARD
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: A logo of a basketball with a sombrero on it.

dialogues.speaker: "LET'S GO AMIGOS
dialogues.text: Welcome to the American Basketball Association. A fan chu his beer and throws some guacamole. The crowd screams and curses at MONIX, mid 40'S -- talent but past his prime. (There are three leading characters i this movie. This is the old rock. Think Nolte in 48 hours Cosner in Durham. Newman in Slap Shot).

dialogues.speaker: LIVE ABA RADIO, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The Amigos are up by one here. They'll need to find a way to stop Monix. He checks the clock, waits... And now drives the lane... MONIX suddenly takes a HUGE HIT, TOTALLY SLAMMED by a big asshole, PETRELLI. He flies into the crowd -- everyone erupts, screaming with glee.

dialogues.speaker: LIVE ABA RADIO, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Ooh, Monix gets taken out hard. Some tough love from Patrelli.

dialogues.speaker: LOU REDWOOD, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: WHAT!? Where's the foul on that? That was all ball. (covering mic, screaming) Jesus Christ Leonard! Let them play for once! This ain't fuckin' Greenpeace!

dialogues.speaker: LIVE ABA RADIO, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Some might say that was a close call, but these referees have done a nice job tonight.

dialogues.speaker: LOU REDWOOD, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: 'Oh please. These refs SUCK. Still stuck in the crowd. Monix struggles to get back on court. The crowd shoves him around, twisting his ankle, slapping him. The crowd is nuts.

dialogues.speaker: DRUNK LADY
dialogues.text: Hey Monix, want a sip? Monix is confused, until the woman throws the beer in his face.

dialogues.speaker: DRUNK LADY
dialogues.text: (smart ass) Oops. She and her friends laugh. Monix says nothing. Instead, h holds his aching back and limps up to the foul line, anno

dialogues.speaker: PATRELLI
dialogues.text: (SMILING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, Monix, I got pushed.

dialogues.speaker: LIVE ABA RADIO, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Well, it looks like the Amigos are in trouble here. Monix is a ninety percent shooter, if he can hit both of these free throws, it's over. Monix performs his ancient free throw ritual: Three dribb and a quick spin of the ball. But he MISSES.

dialogues.speaker: SUCK, MAN
dialogues.text: Again, Monix ignores the drunk lady.

dialogues.speaker: LIVE ABA RADIO, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: They dodged a bullet there. But Monix still has one last chance to tie it up. Monix focuses on his ritual again.

dialogues.speaker: BALL YOU PUSSY
dialogues.text: Monix aims at the basket, about to shoot, but then sudden WHIPS THE BALL HARD AT THE LADY, PEGGING HER IN THE FACE.

dialogues.speaker: LIVE ABA RADIO, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (re: nailing the girl) And the second free throw sails wide.

dialogues.speaker: LOU REDWOOD, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Yes! He just pegged a chick! That's the greatest thing I've ever seen. The lady runs on court and attacks Monix, her boyfriend j in -- Monix hits her boyfriend with some quick hockey punches. The benches clear, everyone is punching everybod

dialogues.speaker: LIVE ABA RADIO, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (re: violent fist fight) And we've got a little bit of pushing and shoving under the basket. What do you make of this, Lou?

dialogues.speaker: LOU REDWOOD, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I'm goin' in. Lou Redwood takes his headphones off, climbs over the announcer's table and jumps into the fight.

dialogues.speaker: LIVE ABA RADIO, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Alright then. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More on this Amigo victory, right after this message from Colt 45.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monix is beat up pretty bad. He dabs his cut with toilet paper.

dialogues.speaker: SCHNACK, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Want one? SCHNACK, the owner, carries a six pack of Schlitz.

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: I'll take two. Schnack hands them over. Monix might speak, but he drinks instead.

dialogues.speaker: SCHNACK
dialogues.text: So, Monix. The trade went through.

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: Really? (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For who?

dialogues.speaker: SCHNACK
dialogues.text: You know, you're not exactly a spring chicken anymore...

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: Just tell me.

dialogues.speaker: SCHNACK
dialogues.text: That score board. ANGLE ON: Pieces of an old scoreboard are crammed into th back of the locker room.

dialogues.speaker: SCHNACK
dialogues.text: It's a Magnovox. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me: What the Hell did you want to get traded back to Flint for, of all places? Please tell me this isn't about Lynn.

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: You still owe me $400.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wide shot of the Flint Michigan skyline.

dialogues.speaker: ECU
dialogues.text: Super-cool CLARENCE WITHERS, 20's African-American, walks around a pet store. This guy is all flash. He spins a bal his finger, but he's more Bootsy Collins than Dr. J.

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (on TV) Don't get all lonely on me people, get yourself a dog or a cat or some- - (studies a weird animal) Or a couple of these, from PET GALAXY. When I'm not dribbling between my legs or sinking jump shots, I'm buying animals. And if this isn't thebeststore in Flint Michigan (re:hisafro) I will shave this off.Nojoke. Make a fast break overtoPET GALAXY. And be sure to tell'emSugar Dunkerton sent you.
With that, Clarence chest-passes the ball out of frame an smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WE PULL BACK to see the TV is on inside a restaurant, Quincy's BBQ. REVEAL: Clarence. The guy from the TV is also a waiter in this restaurant. He's taking an order from some customers

dialogues.speaker: CUSTOMER
dialogues.text: Hey, wasn't that you just now, there on the TV?

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: Yeah, so?

dialogues.speaker: CUSTOMER
dialogues.text: What are you waiting on us for, if you're a basketball star?

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: Who the Hell areyou,the barbecue police? Tell youwhat,I've got the note pad, so I'llaskthe questions: Do youwanta baked potato with that?

dialogues.speaker: CUSTOMER
dialogues.text: The TV said your name was Sugar Dunkerton. How come your name-tag doesn't say that?

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: 'Cause I changed my name, that's why.

dialogues.speaker: CUSTOMER WOMAN
dialogues.text: (reading his name tag) Downtown Funky-Stuff Malone?

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: You like it?

dialogues.speaker: CUSTOMER WOMAN
dialogues.text: I guess it's fine.

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: It ain't fine. (as in smooth) It's fine...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 8 A large woman, QUINCY -- Clarence's Mom -- yells from the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: Shit. (to the customers) It's been a pleasure serving you. Clarence tosses his note pad on the table and his Mother tosses him his duffle bag.

dialogues.speaker: MS. QUINCY
dialogues.text: And don't think I didn't see those cotton briefs of yours in there.

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: Stay outta my stuff!

dialogues.speaker: MS. QUINCY
dialogues.text: Don't you know our ancestors had to pick that cotton? Get yourself some silk underpants. Have some respect.

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: Panties are silk. Briefs are cotton. I'm out of here.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentleman, please rise...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome to Flint Michigan Fairgrounds Coliseum, basketbal end of the world. This is more like a shitty airplane han than a stadium.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: .For the National Anthem... Of your Flint Michigan Tropics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PICTURE 1: The one-hit-wonder, Jackie moon is on an album cover, shirtless, petting a white leopard.

dialogues.text: Baby, who wants to; love me sexy. baby, are you ready to; lick me sexy. PICTURE 2: Jackie Moon in Reno, singing with Pat Boone. H holds up his only hit single. PICTURE 3: Jackie is getting married to LUCY MOON. She's hottest girl in the world.

dialogues.text: Take off your shoes and; suck me sexy. Baby, we're naked and we're; humping sexy-- PICTURE 4: Jackie hands over a giant check, PURCHASING TH FLINT TROPICS.

dialogues.text: Center court, we finally see JACKIE MOON. He sports a per lamb chop sideburns and black frame glasses. He continues sing this song of his own creation...

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: (SINGING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, Baby, who wants to; love me sexy. baby, are you ready to; lick me sexy. Jackie Moon is a sight to see. His one-hit-wonder is ridiculous. But you have to admit it's catchy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE CROWD: Under 100 people are in the stands, but they'r high energy. Lots of drinking and dancing.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Take off your shoes and; suck me sexy. THE BALL GIRLS: They bounce around in shiny-funky hot pan dancing cool, but not in sync. When it comes to ball girl Flint delivers. THE TROPICAL AISLE: A rowdy bunch is decked out in Hawaii shirts and packed in behind the visiter's bench, looking trouble. THE SCOREBOARD: The Magnovox has been sold. The Tropics n do it by hand.

dialogues.text: Baby, we're naked and we're; humping sexy... ANGLE ON DARREN AND JODY: Two kids in WHEEL CHAIRS are pa next to the hardwood, eating nachos and drinking giant co

dialogues.text: (to kids in wheel chairs) Hey there son, what's your name?

dialogues.speaker: WHEELCHAIR DARREN
dialogues.text: Fuck you, Mitchstien.

dialogues.speaker: WHEELCHAIR JODY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Throw any elbows tonight and we'll pound your fuckin' head into the floor. MUSIC CUE: 'TOO HOT TO HANDLE' BY HEATWAVE. With that, the lights go out, PITCH BLACK. A spot light d on Jackie Moon.

dialogues.speaker: LUSCIOUS, FLINT TROPICS ACTION
dialogues.text: The crowd cheers, but not all that loud. Jackie looks off screen and nods off screen. BOBBY DEE works some sound effects, dialing up a knob tha says CROWD NOISE. The speakers are blown, but they're lou
(BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At ball girl, measuring thirty four, twenty two, thirty six, MELIN- DAAAAAAA. MELINDA shakes her perfect measurements in the spotlight, then does a series of cartwheels.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: I'm living a dream, Flint and I know you are too. (Booming voice again) AT GUARD, from Peoria Illinois, six foot one -- this guy's single and he can cook lasagna, I've seen him do it -- TWIGGY -- MUNSONNNNNNN! Bobby Dee hits the disco ball as TWIGGY trots out.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: FROM SOUTH BEND INDIANA, the man with a heart of gold, his brother's a retard, six foot one, he drives down to visit all the time, at forward, he reads to him, BEE BEE

dialogues.speaker: ELLISSSSSSS
dialogues.text: BEE BEE ELLIS does a cartwheel into a round off.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: YOUR MAN IN THE MIDDLE. Seven foot two, from the People's Republic of Uzbechistan, he's tall, he's sensitive -- loves candle light and long walks on the beach -- VAKIDIS

dialogues.speaker: ROSCOVENSKIIIIIIII
dialogues.text: (Vakidis remains seated) Vakidis, that's you man, I called your name. (no response) VAKIDIS! C'mon dude, let's go, get it together. Players push the giant Vakidis out onto the court.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: Now this next guy, where do I start? First of all, that wife of his, she is... Wow. (gesturing re: her chest) CANONS, people. If you know what I'm saying. I don't think she's here tonight, but if she was you'd see what I'm talking about.
He's a small forward, the luckiest man in Flint: SCOOTSIE DOUBLE-

dialogues.speaker: DAYYYYYYY
dialogues.text: Scootsie Double Day 'pops n' locks' his way onto the cour

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: AND FINALLY: The man you've been waiting for, six foot four, a solid, meaty, two hundred fifteen pounds, your pre-game announcer, your owner, your coach, your pop singing sensation, but most importantly, your POWER FORWARD... Yours truly... JACKIE M00000000N!!! Jackie takes off his blazer, twirls it, then tosses it of screen. It's game time. At center court, PLAYER/OWNER/COACH JACKIE huddles them u

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: Alright you guys, let's huddle up! (Vakidis is wandering) Vakidis! Where's he walking to? Kong, get Vakidis. A very short Asian man, KONG, nods. The uniform hangs on tiny body.

dialogues.speaker: KONG
dialogues.text: You got it boss.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: (now huddled up) Let's put on a good show tonight, okay? Let's keep it in the air, keep shooting, look for the baseball pass, launch some early threes to set the tone. Bee Bee, try and do that no-look behind your back thing, I love that, okay? Now let's bring it in. One two three--

dialogues.speaker: EVERYONE
dialogues.text: (TOGETHER)

dialogues.speaker: LET'S GET TROPICAL
dialogues.text: REVEAL: An orange cone sits over a puddle on the court. As the Tropics break the huddle, Jackie talks to the overweight FATHER PAT THE REF.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: (smart ass) Hey, you lose weight, Father Pat?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER PAT THE REF
dialogues.text: Oh, fuck off. What's with the cone tonight Jackie? Jackie points up to a leak in the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: For safety. Just then, Vakidis jogs over, SLIPPING HORRIBLY in the puddle, ripping his groin.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY DEE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (as P.A. Announcer) Okay Tropics fans, it's time to guess today's attendance... Is it A) 9,254. B) 10,506.. or C) 91 TIP OFF: The Tropics gain possession.

dialogues.speaker: LIVE ABA RADIO, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Scootsie drops it in low to player- owner-coach Jackie Moon. Known best for his aggressive defense, leads the team in rebounds. He's an animal under the boards Lou.

dialogues.speaker: LOU REDWOOD, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: You're Damn right. He may not be black, but he can play basketball.

dialogues.speaker: LIVE ABA RADIO, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Now, look at this, Jackie waves the rest of his team away, looking for the isolation. These fans are in for a real treat.

dialogues.speaker: LOU REDWOOD, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: He looks to be setting up his 'Tear Drop from Hades.'

dialogues.speaker: LIVE ABA RADIO, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Jackie is shooting thirty-nine percent from the field, but the crowd always loves to see him go for it.

dialogues.speaker: LOU REDWOOD, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: He's a true showman.
Jackie dribbles hard to the hoop, tossing up a high arcin baby hook. AIRBALL.

dialogues.speaker: LIVE ABA RADIO, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Airball.

dialogues.speaker: LOU REDWOOD, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Yep, a Polish swish.

dialogues.speaker: LIVE ABA RADIO, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Scootsie Double-Day gets the offensive rebound and Jackie calls for it again, trying to establish the low post early. Jackie holds the ball, preparing for another 'Tear Drop f Hades'... But now he suddenly gets distracted by somethin in the stands.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: (into the stands)

dialogues.speaker: DOING, MAN
dialogues.text: IN THE STANDS: A Pakistani vendor, RAVI, IS POURING CHEES SOME NACHOS.

dialogues.speaker: RAVI
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: Enough with the cheese already. More chips, less cheese, how many times do I have to tell you? WHISTLE! Jackie's been walking with the ball. FATHER PAT REF wears a holy collar with pin strips over it.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER PAT THE. REF
dialogues.text: Traveling.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: Traveling!?... On who?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER PAT THE REF
dialogues.text: On you.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: That's bullshit, Father Pat! Jackie, furious, SLAMS THE BALL down on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: LIVE ABA RADIO, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Jackie Moon. The most passionate man in sports.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some hot girls in shorts hold up a sign that says 'ALL ST PARKING.' Ms. Quincy's BBQ delivery truck rips into the l Clarence skids to a stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd looks off camera and suddenly erupts. CLARENCE enters out of the tunnel, he takes a bite of a Hershey bar, then gestures to the crowd, giving the international symbol for 'Let's get funky.'

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY DEE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentleman, put your hands together for Downtown Funky- Stuff Malone! Clarence tosses the half eaten candy bar, wipes his hands on his jersey and jogs right out onto the court during th game, TAGGING HIS TEAMMATE OUT as if it were pick up.

dialogues.speaker: LIVE ABA RADIO, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Downtown, wastes no time entering the game -- tagging out Vakidis Roscovenski.

dialogues.speaker: .CLAWS COACH
dialogues.text: (to the ref) C'mon Father Pat, he's got to check into the game doesn't he? The ref just shrugs. Downtown calls for the ball and gets

dialogues.speaker: LIVE ABA RADIO, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Downtown dribbles left, then right a little shake and bake through the legs -- double teamed now, he's got Twiggy Munson open under the basket. Downtown, still with the ball, dribbles behind his back, they triple him, he's got Munson and Ellis wide open under the hoop, but look at these moves! The entire other team leaves their men and guards Clarenc five on one, but Clarence never passes. His four teammate watch from under the basket.
Despite his selfish attitude, it's clear Clarence actuall has some serious talent.

dialogues.speaker: LIVE ABA RADIO, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Downtown has all five guys on him -- He sprints to the corner and forces up a fade away three... YES! Wow. You think this league's going bankrupt? Well, think again.

dialogues.speaker: LOU REDWOOD, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: People call him selfish. I call him the greatest show in shorts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: An old-timey photo of a man with a handle-bar moustache. It's been autographed by the inventor of basketball: 'Go Tropics! -James Naismith' The team enters the locker room happy, even though they'r losing badly at half time.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: Yes! Nice first half guys! That's what I call Flint Tropic's basketball! (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been telling you all season, we're about to make a run. Flint Michigan is destined for greatness. (at the chalkboard) Twiggy, enough with the bounce passes, let's show some zip. Bee Bee, try not to get fouled so much, free throws take too long. Scootsie, what did I tell you about catching with two hands.? God gave you one hand for a reason: To look awesome. Jackie points to the chalkboard. Where one of his catchy slogans is spelled out.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: Let's stay focused on the four

dialogues.speaker: 'D'S'
dialogues.text: (pointing to the board) Dangerous, Dangerous, Dangerous, Dunks. Remember: This isn't just a basketball team. It's a lifestyle.
Everyone claps. Meanwhile, Clarence grabs a bunch of hair products and goes to work. But he notices something.

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: Yo, Jackie, is the washing machine broken? ANGLE ON: A few workers are taking out the washing machin

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: Listen up guys: I've got some good news and I've got some bad news. The good news is, we're getting rid of that piece of shit washing machine. The bad news is, everyone does their laundry at home from now on. Towels too. Everyone complains. Boo etc. Jackie turns to BOBBY DEE a 'front office' guy.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: And Bobby Dee, I need you to clean out your desk.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY DEE
dialogues.text: No. I have kids.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: You're not fired. I sold your desk.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY DEE
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: (to the team) And I'm going to shed a few lockers, so everyone's getting a locker buddy.

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: Forget that. I need my own locker... For the panty dropper. Clarence reveals his 'panty dropper' a brown full-length leather coat.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: Fine. Now, there's one last thing: I've added some depth to the roster. I think he could deliver some firepower.

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: Firepower? Who'd you hire?

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: At guard, six one, the hometown kid, from your very own Flint Michigan -- He punches in bunches Ed MONIXXXXXXXX! We hear a TOILET FLUSH. Monix exits the bathroom stall buttoning his pants.

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: You're out of toilet paper. Monix doesn't receive a warm welcome. It's more of a star off.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: Okay, now, I know everyone in this room has probably been punched in the face by Monix at one time or another. (Scootsie fumes) One of you may have even had your collar bone broken, twice. But that's in the past now and-

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY DEE, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Yo, Jackie, you're on in two.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: Thanks Bobby. (almost to himself) I love half time. (abruptly to Monix) Anyways, welcome aboard. (LEAVING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One last thing: If you see a possum try and kill it. With that, Jackie leaves. Monix faces his team in silence

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: So. Who wants to be my locker buddy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's half time show. Jackie has pulled a lucky contestant from the audience.

DUKES, the contestant, is shirtless with jeans, with a st spangled bandana over a mullet. He plays with a ball a little. A giant five by ten check is propped up, with the words ' THOUSAND DOLLARS' written in glitter.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: Ladies and Gentleman, this man is about to attempt the impossible. The $10,000 full court shot. So, tell me, what's your name?

dialogues.speaker: DUKES
dialogues.text: Dukes.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: Okay, Dukes. You feeling it?

dialogues.speaker: DUKES
dialogues.text: Yeah dude.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: What are you going to spend all of your money on if you win? A shirt?

dialogues.speaker: DUKES
dialogues.text: Yeah man, a shirt. Ha! Whoooo!

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: Okay people, Dukes is excited. Let's get some clapping going as he prepares himself for the impossible. (leading the clapping) This is drama, folks! C'mon now, let's hear it! The $10,000 shot people, let's hear it!!! For the first time, Dukes looks kind of serious. He sizes the distant hoop...

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: (doing play by play) He looks ready... And... Here he goes! An uncoordinated baseball pass... Sailing off into the distance... And...

dialogues.speaker: SWISH
dialogues.text: The crowd can't believe their eyes.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: Shit.

dialogues.speaker: MIRACLE
dialogues.text: Jackie is freaking out. Dukes has just won $10,000! Dukes runs around court, shirtless, leaping in celebration.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: (to Father Pat the Ref) Did he step on the line?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER PAT THE REF
dialogues.text: No, it was legal. He made it.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: Who the Hell has $10,000? I sure he stepped on the line, you know what I'm saying?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER PAT THE REF
dialogues.text: (getting the hint) Listen to this crowd. You can't screw a kid over like that. People will kill you. He's right. The crowd is too hyped for Jackie to explain he's broke.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: (accepting his fate) Fuck me.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: (pretending to be happy)

dialogues.speaker: THOUSAND DOLLARS
dialogues.text: (faking it to the crowd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beautiful, down to earth woman, LYNN, 30's, is reading book. In the background, her boyfriend, KYLE, is listenin the Tropics game on the RADIO.

dialogues.speaker: LIVE ABA RADIO, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Monix was an All-American at Michigan State, but then went on to a disappointing journeyman career in the NBA. But he did manage to sit on the bench with the world champion Boston Celtics years ago and won a ring.

dialogues.speaker: LOU REDWOOD, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (on radio) I should hire his agent. Kyle listens to this and yells to the other room.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: Hey honey, guess who got traded to Flint?

dialogues.speaker: LYNN
dialogues.text: I don't know, who?

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: Monix. The word Monix stops her in her tracks.

dialogues.speaker: LYNN
dialogues.text: Monix?

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: Yeah! He's already got an NBA ring, but he's still playing... In Flint. Can you believe it?

dialogues.speaker: LYNN
dialogues.text: No, I can't. Lynn closes her book, fidgety...

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: They say he asked to be traded. Who the Hell leaves California to come here? I love this guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie cruises the streets of Flint in a pimped out Monte Carlo. He's got chrome rims and a gold grill. The interio wall to wall carpeting. He swigs a beer as he turns.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: (singing with car stereo) Get the funk outta-of-my-face... A SIGN SAYS: THE KREMLIN. Jackie rolls up and parks in a reserved parking space. He rolls up the windows and locks doors by hand and exits.

dialogues.speaker: REVEAL
dialogues.text: Patrick Ewing style, right over his slacks. A police officer drinks, in uniform, outside.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: What's up Jackie?

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: Not much.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: (re: the big ice packs) Your knees okay?

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: Oh yeah. Just icing them down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'The Kremlin' is rocking. The beer is served in cans only

dialogues.speaker: BALL GIRL MAGGIE, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Hey Jackie!

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: Well look at you! You look beautiful. What's different?

dialogues.speaker: BALL GIRL MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I dyed my hair.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: No, that's not it... Did your tits get bigger?

dialogues.speaker: BALL GIRL MAGGIE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: Don't lie to me. Those things got bigger.

dialogues.speaker: BALL GIRL MAGGIE
dialogues.text: No, they're the same.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: Well, good job. Jackie keeps walking, bumping into MS. QUINCY, Clarence's mother.

dialogues.speaker: MS. QUINCY
dialogues.text: Yo Jackie. You know, that wife of yours has been making out with that Mark Spitz lookin' motherfucker all night. She gestures to a guy who's lip-locked with Jackie's wife LUCY MOON unbuttons her fur coat.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: Oh. It's okay, Lucy and I've got an open relationship.

dialogues.speaker: MS. QUINCY
dialogues.text: I know that. But he's about to suck on her Damn tits, right here in front of all these people.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: She's hot right? What can I say, we're freedom lovers. (calling off to his wife) Hey honey! Lucy Moon ignores him, only making out harder.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: (to his wife) Right on! (to Quincy) I'm not jealous. It's a sweet deal for both of us.

dialogues.speaker: MS. QUINCY
dialogues.text: Have you ever slept with another woman?

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: I could. That's the beauty of it. No ball and chain here.
I can just go for it. You know, if I ever get invited to some cool orgy, it's definitely not a problem at all.

dialogues.speaker: MS. QUINCY
dialogues.text: Have you ever been to an orgy?

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: Pshh. Are you kidding? When haven't I been?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MONIX is hanging out with Bee Bee Ellis, Scootsie Double and Twiggy Munson. They all do a shot together.

dialogues.speaker: BEE BEE ELLIS
dialogues.text: I heard Jackie is going to go to some owner's meeting. What do you think that's about?

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: I don't know, but it can't be good.

dialogues.speaker: TWIGGY MUNSON
dialogues.text: Hey, let's see that championship ring, Monix.

dialogues.speaker: SCOOTSIE DOUBLE-DAY
dialogues.text: Yeah, you promised we could see the ice. Monix takes the ring out. It hangs from his neck.

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: Look at this piece. It says Celtics right there in diamonds.

dialogues.speaker: SCOOTSIE DOUBLE-DAY
dialogues.text: Why don't you wear it on your finger?

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: I don't know, I just like to wear it around my neck, that's all. NOW CLARENCE chimes in without looking over...

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: Not everyone sits around dreaming of playing in the NBA, you know.

dialogues.speaker: SCOOTSIE DOUBLE-DAY
dialogues.text: Maybe not. But you do.

dialogues.speaker: TWIGGY MUNSON
dialogues.text: Yeah, that's all you ever talk about.

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: You're not jealous, are you Clarence?

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: No one calls me Clarence.

dialogues.speaker: BEE BEE ELLIS
dialogues.text: His name's Downtown.

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: Okay Downtown. I'll make sure Downtown is only referred to as Downtown, okay Downtown?

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: Don't think I don't know what you're doing. You're doing that thing where you pretend to mean what you say, but you don't.

dialogues.speaker: BEE BEE ELLIS
dialogues.text: Sarcasm.

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: Yeah. How'd you like that sarcasm smacked off your face?

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: Bring it, funky stuff.

dialogues.speaker: BEE BEE ELLIS
dialogues.text: That's sarcasm, man. He's doing it again!

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: (to Bee Bee) I got this, alright? Monix squares off with a smile that says 'hit me.' Claren takes off his leather full length and folds it nicely.

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: (in Monix's face) How'd you like a knuckle sandwich?

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: Knuckle sandwich? Who says that?

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: I do motherfucker. I'm gonna pound you so hard, you're-- MONIX REARS HIS FIST BACK, about to release a strong Pope

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: (like a sissy)

dialogues.speaker: TEAM, BUT I LIKE IT.
dialogues.text: One of the party people, a ball girl, GAYLE, interrupts.

dialogues.speaker: GAYLE
dialogues.text: Excuse me boys. You mind, if I borrow your friend for a minute?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie is dancing to his own song, still wearing the ice packs on his knees. The song ends and A DIFFERENT ONE STA

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: (looking to the DJ) Hold on a second.

dialogues.speaker: MELINDA
dialogues.text: What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: Where's the boogie? Jackie fights his way through the crowd to the DJ booth.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: (to DJ, over music)

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: (taking over as DJ)

dialogues.speaker: PATROL.
dialogues.text: SCREECH -- The music stops.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: (into the mic) The year was 1973. A young musician named Jackie Moon, finishes years of musical training, only to find he is a slave to the notes on the page. He knows it's time to break free. In a sudden fit of creative mastery, he grabs a pen and a napkin and writes a song that breaks all the rules. Ladies and gentleman... Let's get sweaty. MUSIC CUE: Jackie's song. Everyone goes crazy.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (studio version) Baby, who wants to; love me sexy. baby, are you ready to; lick me sexy. Take off your shoes and; suck me sexy. Baby, we're naked and we're; humping sexy--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gayle and Monix walk upstairs into the 'coolest' room eve Carpet on the ceiling, a plaid couch, a fish tank, a wate bed, mirrors, etc.

dialogues.speaker: GAYLE
dialogues.text: I'm glad they traded for you, I got myself a cute one.

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: So, this is the Daiquiri room?

dialogues.speaker: LUCY MOON, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: That's right. REVEAL: LUCY MOON, Jackie's wife, is on the couch. She's hottest girl in the world.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY MOON
dialogues.text: What do you think, Gayle? Does he like it with my boots on, or does he like my boots off?

dialogues.speaker: GAYLE
dialogues.text: He seems like a boots on kind of guy.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY MOON
dialogues.text: Then it looks like I'm ready. As soon as you slide these shorts off of me.

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: Aren't you Jackie's wife?

dialogues.speaker: LUCY MOON
dialogues.text: He knows about the Daiquiri room.

dialogues.speaker: GAYLE
dialogues.text: It's a new tradition we're starting, when new players join.

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: I see. Well, I'm going to have to pass. I'm good, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY MOON
dialogues.text: Honey, you don't know what good is. With that, Lucy flicks on the stereo--

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: Listen um... (i.e. what's your name?)

dialogues.speaker: GAYLE
dialogues.text: My name is 'no strings attached.'

dialogues.speaker: LUCY MOON
dialogues.text: You can call me Mrs. Moon. Gayle and Lucy perform a funky/seductive dance, moving cl and closer to Monix.

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: I don't think this is going to happen, Mrs. Moon.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY MOON
dialogues.text: It has to.

dialogues.speaker: GAYLE
dialogues.text: It's bad luck if you don't.

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'd hate to bring bad luck to Flint Michigan. Lucy has sprayed some WHIP CREAM on her nipples.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY MOON
dialogues.text: (whip cream) Why don't you lick these clean for me?

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: I can't eat dairy. Lucy decides that now is a good time to aggressively KISS him. Monix pushes her away.

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: Nice tits, Mrs. Moon. I gotta go. Monix walks down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY MOON
dialogues.text: (calling after him) I see what this is: You want us to send Eric and Marcus up here? On the way out, Monix flicks her off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lynn is asleep next to Kyle. She awakes to someone poundi on the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lynn has arrived at the screen door. Monix, wasted, doesn notice Lynn yet, he keeps pounding until she opens it.

dialogues.speaker: LYNN
dialogues.text: Why are you here?

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: I got traded.

dialogues.speaker: LYNN
dialogues.text: I mean, why are you here?

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: Can we talk?

dialogues.speaker: KYLE, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: --Yo, Monix, you're wasted! Ha! Kyle has come out to say hi.

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: Yeah. Sorry man--

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: What's up! That of jump shot of yours ain't broke yet, is it?

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: No. Ha.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: Great back door cut for the lay-up in the third. That's how basketball should be played.

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: Kyle, can you give us a second? We need to talk.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: No problem. Great game tonight man.

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: Why does your boyfriend like me so much?

dialogues.speaker: LYNN
dialogues.text: You're his favorite player.

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: Look, there are still some things I think we need to talk about.

dialogues.speaker: LYNN
dialogues.text: I've already said everything I'm ever going to say to you.

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: I see. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I guess I'll be leaving then. Monix walks away... Then turns back.

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: You're really not going to stop me?

dialogues.speaker: LYNN
dialogues.text: No. Monix walks more, until Lynn speaks.

dialogues.speaker: LYNN
dialogues.text: You're going to end up walking with a cane the rest of your life. You have to quit.

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: And do what?

dialogues.speaker: LYNN
dialogues.text: I don't know... Kill yourself, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: Kill myself?

dialogues.speaker: LYNN
dialogues.text: You act like there's nothing else in the world besides basketball. If that's how you really feel, then go ahead and get it over with. I'm going to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: Thanks for the pep. talk.

dialogues.speaker: LYNN
dialogues.text: No problem.

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: Lynn. (she opens the door again) Can I ask you for one favor?

dialogues.speaker: LYNN
dialogues.text: You want a favor?

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: My knee.

dialogues.speaker: LYNN
dialogues.text: Oh, Jesus Christ Monix. It's 4 a.m. Lynn stares at him in disbelief. Monix shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: No one here can drain it right.

dialogues.speaker: LYNN
dialogues.text: Fine. Monix nods, then makes a move toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: LYNN
dialogues.text: No. You're not coming in. We'll do it in the yard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie drives in his car, practicing for the meeting. tri to build some confidence.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: (into the rear view, very

dialogues.speaker: CIVILIZED
dialogues.text: Well, hello Commissioner -- Why sure, I would love one of your Puerto Rican cigars -- Oh, I know I'm a legitimate owner, you don't have to tell me that -- We're merging with the NBA? Oh, that's nice -- Ha Ha Ha! Good one, Commish ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A brick building on the outskirts of Indianapolis. A sign says. WELCOME ABA OWNERS. Jackie pulls into the lot and parks. He looks in the mirror one last time.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: Your Mom would be proud of you today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not-quite-Rich guys surround a large oak table. JACKIE is far the youngest of the owners.

dialogues.speaker: COMMISH
dialogues.text: .I'm sure each of you have heard the rumors. And I'm here to tell you, the rumors are true. The ABA will be merging with the NBA at the end of this season.

dialogues.speaker: YES
dialogues.text: (to an old guy)

dialogues.speaker: GIVE ME TEN, NORTON
dialogues.text: (fists to the ceiling)

dialogues.speaker: COMMISH
dialogues.text: Our league is sold. And the NBA agreed to all of our financial demands! Now Jackie turns inward, more quietly intense. This is, without question, the greatest moment of his life.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: (to himself) You're a real owner. You're in the NBA.

dialogues.speaker: COMMISH
dialogues.text: Four of our teams will be absorbed into the NBA family, the rest of you will terminate operations.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: Exactly! You know it! (now hearing) I'm sorry, wait, what?

dialogues.speaker: COMMISH
dialogues.text: The Nuggets, The Nets, The Spurs and the Pacers will play in the NBA next year. The rest of us will dissolve.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: Dissolve? Dissolve, like, how? How do I dissolve into the NBA? The winning owners look at each other, not sure how to ha Jackie.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: What's happening?

dialogues.speaker: COMMISH
dialogues.text: I'm sorry Jackie. We all know how. emotional you get. We waited until the very last second to tell you. Jackie pounds the table.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: No. NO! NO!!! He kicks over his chair...

dialogues.speaker: THE COMMISH
dialogues.text: We know you're upset, Jackie. But you'll be very well compensated.

dialogues.speaker: LOSING OWNER
dialogues.text: Everyone's agreed to a very large sum.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: I don't want a sum! I want my team! (to the losing owners) C'mon you guys, you're not going to just sit here and take the money, are you? They are.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: (to winning owners) What do the Spurs have that we don't?

dialogues.speaker: THE COMMISH
dialogues.text: A huge fan base. A brand new stadium. A solid economic growth package, including strong tax incentives.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: Oh, c'mon, that's BULLSHIT!

dialogues.speaker: COMMISH
dialogues.text: The NBA is taking four teams, Jackie, there's nothing I can do. Jackie goes quiet, thinking... An epic idea hits him.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: The best four teams should go.

dialogues.speaker: COMMISH
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: Forget the huge fan base, the stadiums, the economic... (a little lost) Growing... package... inventions...

dialogues.speaker: WINNING OWNER
dialogues.text: (correcting him) Economic growth pack--

dialogues.speaker: I KNOW WHAT I SAID
dialogues.text: (to the room) The four teams with the best records should merge.

dialogues.speaker: LOSING OWNER
dialogues.text: He's right.

dialogues.speaker: LOSING OWNER
dialogues.text: Yeah, that's the fairest way.

dialogues.speaker: COMMISH
dialogues.text: These four teams DO have the best records. Flint's only won six games all year!

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: So far. The season isn't over.

dialogues.speaker: LOSING OWNER
dialogues.text: Yeah, maybe we should finish the season first.

dialogues.speaker: COMMISH
dialogues.text: This plan sounds like a lot of fun, but it's too late. The commissioner, me, has already decided.

dialogues.speaker: LOSING OWNER
dialogues.text: Actually, the terms of a merger can only be approved by a league mandate.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: YES. That's right. What he said.

dialogues.speaker: LOSING OWNER
dialogues.text: I move that we vote on the terms of the merger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The team sits around the parking lot, sitting on their du bags, dejected. Jackie is having a team meeting.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: C'mon you guys, let's try to stay psyched. This is a chance to become a real NBA franchise!

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: There's no way we can make it to fourth place. It's mathematically impossible.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: I ran the numbers. All we have to do is win about eighty-two percent of our remaining games.

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: Eighty-two percent? Isn't that a lot?

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: Oh, c'mon! We just gotta start hitting our threes. (guys look around, unsure) Listen, I know this seems like bad news, but it doesn't have to be. This is a big road trip for us. We've just got to start playing solid Flint basketball.

dialogues.speaker: SCOOTSIE DOUBLE-DAY
dialogues.text: I don't know. We suck, man. JACKIE SLAPS SCOOTSIE.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: (re: The slap) Sorry. JACKIE SLAPS HIM AGAIN, HARDER.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: We do not suck, okay? We just have to want it!
Pumped, Jackie walks around with his hands on his hips.

dialogues.speaker: BEE BEE ELLIS
dialogues.text: What do you think, Monix? All eyes turn on the grumpy one.

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: I think we suck.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: Well... See, now there's some team unity! Now let's load up the jet. REVEAL: A SHITTY SCHOOL BUS has the words 'THE JET!' Spra painted in graffiti letters with a palm tree next to it.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: (as they load up) Now we've got a special treat. You know I take care of my family. Today, the Jet is catered. I had Downtown's Mom pack us some hot dish.

dialogues.speaker: BEE BEE ELLIS
dialogues.text: Ms. Quincy's hot dish? Sweet!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guys load up. It's so packed it's ridiculous. Everyon tries to stuff their gear somewhere and sit down. Jackie carries a big pot of hot dish, accidentally burnin Scootsie's back.

dialogues.speaker: SCOOTSIE DOUBLE-DAY
dialogues.text: Ah, watch the hot dish, man.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: Sorry Scootsie.

dialogues.speaker: TWIGGY MUNSON
dialogues.text: Hey Jackie, there's some dude out there, wants to talk to you. POV: Out the window, we can see DUKES, the full court sho winner, holding his GIANT CHECK and looking into the bus. He's still shirtless, with a star-spangled headband.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie and Dukes are next to the bus, discussing the chec

dialogues.speaker: DUKES
dialogues.text: I tried Jackie. They won't take it. They said it's 'symbolic.'

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: What does symbolic mean?

dialogues.speaker: DUKES
dialogues.text: I don't know. But they said I need a real check.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: I don't know what your bank is talking about. That is a real check. I signed it myself.

dialogues.speaker: DUKES
dialogues.text: It's written in glitter, dude. Can't you just give me, like, a regular sized one?

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: I don't get it. People are usually able to cash these. Maybe you should try another bank. (trying to wrap it up) If you run into any more trouble, let me know.

dialogues.speaker: DUKES
dialogues.text: Okay Jackie, thanks man.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: Any time, congratulations. Jackie turns away from Dukes and exhales, walking back to bus. MUSIC CUE: 'SHORT PEOPLE' BY RANDY NEWMAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're flying down the highway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kong, the small Asian player, is driving, singing along w Jackie to the radio... JACKIE MOON & KONG (singing Randy Newman) SHORT PEOPLE GOT, NO REASON...

dialogues.speaker: SHORT PEOPLE GOT, NO REASON TO LIVE
dialogues.text: Jackie reaches up into a special bin and takes out some b jerky, then yells out the window.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: (out the window at a car)

dialogues.speaker: TO LIVE...
dialogues.text: Pan back to see the whole team crammed into tiny seats. Vakidis has his knees pointing straight toward the ceilin Twiggy Munson is reading '70's pornography. Clarence is sewing a new name onto his jersey. The rest of the guys a eating their hot dish.

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: So, Clarence, what's in this 'hot dish' anyway?

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: My Mom cooked your ass a whole Damn meal, why you gotta go asking what's in it?

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: It's a compliment. It's good.

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: If it's good, then it's good. Why do you gotta know what's in it? What's in hot dish? Hot dish is in hot dish, asshole. BEE BEE and SCOOTSIE look over the seat, facing them.

dialogues.speaker: BEE BEE ELLIS
dialogues.text: Hey Monix, what were the Celtics like?

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: They were fast.

dialogues.speaker: SCOOTSIE DOUBLE-DAY
dialogues.text: Fast? No one's faster than me. I should be on the Celtics.

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: (pointing to his mind) Fast up here.

dialogues.speaker: BEE BEE ELLIS
dialogues.text: You're supposed to be Mr. Smartball. Why'd you get bounced?

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: Well, you have to be able to jump too.

dialogues.speaker: SCOOTSIE DOUBLE-DAY
dialogues.text: Hey, let us see that ring again.

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: Not right now, okay Twiggy?

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: Isn't it a little embarrassing wearing that thing everyday?

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: Embarrassing?

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: You call yourself a Celtic? You sat through every single playoff game. You didn't see action once. And now you walk around wearing the ice like you're Bill Russel. Well you ain't.

dialogues.speaker: BEE BEE ELLIS
dialogues.text: Oh, you're just jealous.

dialogues.speaker: SCOOTSIE DOUBLE-DAY
dialogues.text: Yeah, Monix played solid minutes, for lots of teams. He's played in the NBA, that's more than you can say.

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: Whatever. At least I never sat on the bench and then called myself a champion. You didn't do shit for that Celtic team. If I was Dave Cowens, I'd yank that ring right off your neck. That was a pretty heated exchange. Monix looks like he's something to say, but he doesn't. Clarence has the last w

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: He doesn't wear it on his finger because he knows he didn't earn it. He didn't even play.
Monix looks out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'The Jet' is parked outside the arena.

dialogues.speaker: LIVE ABA RADIO, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: We're just a few minutes away from game one of the Tropic's 6 game road trip. With talk of an NBA merger hitting the league, there's a new electricity surrounding tonight's game...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie addresses his team before tip off.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: Alright. Now, a lot of people out there are writing us off. A lot people are saying things like 'Jackie Moon is an offensive liability.' They're saying 'Flint's turnovers led to sixty fast break points per game.' (Making this up) They're saying 'Bee Bee's retarded brother is so retarded that his eyes look too big,. Like a French Bulldog.

dialogues.speaker: BEE BEE ELLIS
dialogues.text: No one said that, man.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: (trying to motivate) Yes they did. And we're going to use it as motivation, okay? THIS IS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GAME 1) JACKIE MOON sprints across the floor tries to get f eet planted in the lane. It's not even close, JACKIE HA TAKEN A GUY DOWN HARD. The ref whistles a blocking foul.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: OH, C'MON!? Where's the charge, Father Pat?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER PAT THE REF
dialogues.text: Both feet weren't planted.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER PAT THE REF
dialogues.text: That's it, you're out.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: What!? What did I say? Jackie takes a ball and drop kicks it, PUNTING IT high up into the rafters. BUZZER! FINAL SCORE: COLONELS 111 TROPICS 92. GAME 2) MONIX drives the lane, fast and smart -- A no-loo pass hits Scootsie Double-Day in the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: BUZZER
dialogues.text: GAME 3) CLARENCE and BEE BEE jog back on Defense.

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: I ain't guarding my guy anymore.

dialogues.speaker: BEE BEE ELLIS
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: He's too'Damn sweaty, man. (re: his wet uniform) Look at me.

dialogues.speaker: BEE BEE ELLIS
dialogues.text: Gross. Well, I ain't guarding him. Monix notices this discussion.

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: Quit talking and play defense! The sweaty guy backs in on Clarence, posting up top.
GAME 5) Jackie Moon plays great defense, rejecting a shot Monix grabs the ball and dribbles on a fast break. Claren trails, in perfect position...

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: Right on! I'm open baby! Try a behind-the-back! Monix delivers a nice two handed bounce pass, but Clarenc isn't ready for anything fundamentally sound -- The ball him in the nuts.

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: Ah, shit. BUZZER! FINAL SCORE: PIPERS 105 TROPICS 91.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angle on a big hotel with fancy lights -- but then we pan reveal: A shitty motel. The 'Jet' is parked at the cheap place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two twin beds in a crap-box motel room. Monix has the pho to his ear, but it just keeps ringing. He'd leave a messa for Lynn, but answering machines haven't been invented ye He hangs up, looks in the mirror, and now takes his Championship ring necklace off. He looks at the ring in his hand... And shoves it into hi duffle bag.

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: I brought us some ice. Monix is startled. Clarence, his roommate for the night, enters.

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: Ice? What for?

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: I don't know, it's free. Clarence takes some ice, pops it in his mouth and starts crunching.

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: Want some?

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: No thanks. Now BEE BEE enters, yet another player in the small room.

dialogues.speaker: BEE BEE ELLIS
dialogues.text: That Root Beer machine took my fucking change, man. White people are assholes. Monix ignores this. Laying back, he focuses on the TV: TH CELTICS are playing. Their trapping defense is a thing of beauty. Clarence walks over and flicks the channels, until he sto at 'Love American Style.'

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: You turned off the Celtics?

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: I don't watch people play basketball. They watch me. With that, Clarence pulls out a JOINT and lights it.

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: (re: the marijuana) What the Hell is that?

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: (as he inhales) It's a fucking Egg-McMuffin. Monix opens the window, clearing the pot smoke out of his face. JACKIE EXITS the bathroom, having just taken a shower. He wearing a very small robe. This is now the fourth player who's sleeping in this tiny room.

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: Why don't you shower in your room?

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: My wife is using it. I'll be crashing with you guys tonight. (NOTICING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ice? Awesome. (as he eats ice, re: TV) Love American Style? Turn it up.
Jackie doesn't say a word about the pot. Instead he keeps eyes glued to the TV, then reaches for the joint and SMOK IT.

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: Jackie, have you ever even slept with your wife?

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: (LYING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Are you kidding? Try, like, every weekend. She's so hot.

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: Sounds like a great arrangement.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: You guys need to wake up. Quit living like it's the 1950's, man. Live it up. (showing off) Hey Clarence, let's have some of that smoke, bro.

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: I'm pretty sure we have a game tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: (as he inhales) This stuff won't affect you. It's premium. Jackie finishes inhaling, then holds it out for Monix. He stares at the joint, then around the room at his teammate

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: Well, if this is really going to be my life, I might as well be stoned like everyone else.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: Well said. Monix takes the stupid joint. The instant Monix inhales h COUGHS LIKE CRAZY.

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: What the Hell is this?

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: It's harsh.

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: Take that back.

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: Take what back?

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: His Mom grows it.

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: Yeah, in the yard.

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: Your Mom grew this?

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: It's sweet grass.

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: Well, I'm finished, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: What's wrong, my Mom's weed ain't good enough for you?

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: I guess not.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: C'mon man, have some respect for his Mom's weed.

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: That's it, I ain't sleeping in the same bed as this motherfucker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Television cameras are being set up. A camera man cleans lens. Jackie studies the cameras, mesmerized by the idea of television. He speaks with the Amigo's manager.

dialogues.speaker: AMIGO MANAGER
dialogues.text: You want all the fans to sit on one side of the stadium?

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: Yeah, just move all those people over to this side. (DEMONSTRATING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, the TV cameras are going to face this way, right? Well, if we fill the seats on that side, we'll look sold out.

dialogues.speaker: AMIGO MANAGER
dialogues.text: Actually, that's not a bad idea. MEANWHILE, ON THE COURT: Both teams are warming up. Clare now has a new name on his Jersey. There are so many words there is barely space for a number. It's a mess.

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: (re: Jersey, new name) Check it out. I sewed it on the bus.

dialogues.speaker: SCOOTSIE DOUBLE-DAY
dialogues.text: (struggling to read it) What's it say?

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: Jumping Johnny Johnson. The asshole, PETRELLI, wanders over near the Tropics side the court.

dialogues.speaker: PETRELLI
dialogues.text: Yo, Granny Yarn Barn, how's the needle point going?

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: Kiss my ass, Petrelli.

dialogues.speaker: PETRELLI
dialogues.text: (re: the Jersey name) Hey man, I think you spelled 'Flint sucks balls' wrong. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This guy's the next Betsy Ross! Aren't you Clarence? The guys laugh. MONIX walks up, defending his teammate.

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: No one calls him Clarence. His name

dialogues.speaker: IS--
dialogues.text: (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: Jumping Johnny Johnson.

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: His name's Jumping Johnny Johnson. (nose to nose) You got that? Jackie hurries over.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: Alright, break it up. (to his team) Everyone huddle up!... VAKIDIS! OVER HERE. Where is he walking to? (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck it. Listen up, we're on National TV tonight. And you all know what that means: The league needs a good clean game.

dialogues.speaker: BEE BEE ELLIS
dialogues.text: Oh, that's a bunch of dog shit.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: Hey! You guys want to merge or not? Because the fastest way to screw this up is to start punching people in the face while the commissioner is at home, watching the game with his kids... Children are very impressionable. Their minds are not yet soiled by the cruel realities of this world.

dialogues.speaker: BEE BEE ELLIS
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: No punching. Behind the huddle, FANS BEGIN WALKING RIGHT ACROSS THE CO Both teams turn to watch this strange thing. The Amigos manager leads the herd, Jackie helps out, directing them across to the other side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The optical illusion has worked. The game does indeed loo crowded. The game is in full swing.

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: This sold out crowd is loving this one, the Amigos up by twenty-six here in the second. Monix drains a nice jumper, but out of nowhere, Petrelli, guy we hate, throws a hard shoulder, knocking Monix to th floor.

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: That's a moving pick Father Pat! C'mon!

dialogues.speaker: FATHER PAT THE REF
dialogues.text: Play on. Monix can't believe it. Petrelli taunts Monix.

dialogues.speaker: PETRELLI
dialogues.text: What's wrong Monix, cat got your 'nads? Monix faces off.

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: (POINTING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not with the cameras. (miming the commish') He's watching. Monix looks around and thinks...

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: What about commercials?

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: Commercials, what about commercials? Jackie thinks about this, then nods 'good idea.'

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: I like it. Time out Ref!

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: A time out on the floor, 5:20 left before the half, the Amigos 45, the Tropics 19, we'll be right back after this message from Shasta. The camera's on air' red light turns off.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERA MAN
dialogues.text: (rooting them on) And... You're clear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The commissioner relaxes at home with his two kids... A Shasta commercial is on TV.

dialogues.speaker: SHASTA COMMERCIAL, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (on TV) I want a pop... I want a -- Shasta...

dialogues.speaker: KONG
dialogues.text: Hi-Ya! MEANWHILE: MONIX AND PETRELLI ARE TRADING HOCKEY PUNCHES.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERA MAN
dialogues.text: And we're back in -5- (Monix punches Petrelli) -4- (Petrelli punches Monix) -3- (Monix punches Petrelli)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 52 -2- (Monix ducks and punches) (cuing the announcers) AND WE'RE ON. THE 'RED LIGHT' GLOWS.

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Welcome back to the ABA game of the week... Players hold their heads in pain. Others limp back to the bench.

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: .The camaraderie and spirit of this league is on full display here tonight... Off camera, Monix delivers a secret punch to Patrelli's spleen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie runs the half time talk, standing in front of the chalk board.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: Okay, solid first half guys, but we're going to have to make some

dialogues.speaker: ADJ--
dialogues.text: Monix interrupts Jackie, pissed. He addresses the team, stepping in front of Jackie Moon.

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: --This is bullshit guys. They're kicking our ass in basketball and they're kicking our ass during the commercials, too. Does anybody here understand the concept of the pick and roll? Because they're going to keep double teaming at the top of the key until somebody rotates the Damn ball...

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: Yeah! C'mon guys! Rotate the ball. Monix looks at this group and gets even madder.

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: Does anyone in this room have any pride? Don't you realize, this is thelast four weeks of basketball anyus are ever going to play?Is thishow we're really going togo out?You'd think we'd want toend ourcareers battling, hustling after every loose ball. Boxing out under the boards. Setting picks for our teammates. But we haven't done shit out there. Twiggy Munson and Scootsie Double-Day hang their heads.

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: We're a bunch of selfish assholes -- And I've got news for you, we aren't going to finish in fourth, we're going to finish dead last. Monix paces in front of the guys, a man possessed.

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: One day, you're going to look back on your life... And you're going to look back on this time... And you're going to realize... Monix is staring right at Clarence. And Clarence is actua listening...

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: .You're going to realize you never even played basketball. A moment of silence after the intensity. Monix waddles to door.

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: Now, you guys have fun out there in the second half. If anyone needs me, I'll be in the training room, draining my knee. Monix limps off, everyone's head is hanging low.

dialogues.speaker: SCOOTSIE DOUBLE-DAY
dialogues.text: He's right.

dialogues.speaker: BEE BEE ELLIS
dialogues.text: Of course he's right. But what the Hell are we supposed to do about it? We don't even have plays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're back in Flint. Jackie is back in his office, speaki on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: (into phone) Dukes! I don't make the rules. If they can't cash it, maybe you'll have to go out of state. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would if I could, but if I give you another check, that would be two checks. That would be $20,000, not ten. What are you trying to pull here? (the other line rings) I've got to take this other call Dukes. Bye!-- (hits a button, answering) Flint Tropics hot line... Oh hey Commish ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the floor, instead of a basketball court, the stadium holds an ice-rink. A 'Welcome to the Flint Ice Capades' s is being removed. The entire basketball team is on their hands and knees ASSEMBLING THE HARD WOOD. This is a lot of work. Clarence hits his thumb with a hammer.

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: Why do we have to put the court together?

dialogues.speaker: SCOOTSIE DOUBLE-DAY
dialogues.text: I guess the Ice Capades sold out.

dialogues.speaker: BEE BEE ELLIS
dialogues.text: Yeah, kids love that stuff. Although, I find the wild-life masks realistic and frightening.

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: Monix should be here helping us.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Guys. The guys look up to find Jackie. He does not look happy.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: The commissioner just called.

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: I looks like we've got ourselves a situation. We've got some new 'terms and conditions' for this merger deal.

dialogues.speaker: SCOOTSIE DOUBLE-DAY
dialogues.text: What'd he say?

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: Basically, we've got to average at least 2,000 fans per home game for the rest of the year.

dialogues.speaker: TWIGGY MUNSON
dialogues.text: 2,000 people? Every home game?

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: He said the NBA will only take a franchise that has fans.

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: Shit. Winning is going to be hard. But getting 2,000 people to watch is going to be impossible.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON
dialogues.text: Let's try and stay positive. My Mother always believed Flint was a town of destiny. And I believe that. Now, I've already started work on a huge idea to promote us.

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: What kind of huge idea?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie's place is empty. Monix is drinking alone, totally blasted in the middle of the day. He hangs his head, bare able to order.

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: Two more Johnny Walkers. And another pack of Kools.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: You could use some fresh air, Monix. You want to take a nap in the back of my truck?

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: (ANGRY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just the drinks and the smokes, alright? (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have any idea where Lynn is these days?

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: She asked me to tell you to quit going to her house.

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: Well, tell her that's just fine with me.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Okay. Sorry man.

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Monix. REVEAL: Clarence.

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: Well, well, well, look who it is. (to the bartender) Brian, I'd like you to meet Jumping Johnny Downtown Funky stuff Boner- time finger-blast Fag-erton.

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: (to the bartender) Johnny for short. (to Brian, re: Monix) Two coffees.

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: So, what brings you to the The Kremlin?

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: Listen, I know you and I haven't always been the best of buddies.
But I've been thinking about what you said the other night. This is gonna be our last chance. If I'm ever going to get into the NBA, it's going to be with the Tropics.

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: I hate to break it to you, Clarence, but the Tropics will never play in the NBA.

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: So maybe we won't. But like you said, I don't want to look back on this with any regrets. I know what you think of me. But I'm willing to put our differences aside. I'm telling you right now, I'll do whatever it takes to win.

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: You mean, like, pass?

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: (with a smile) I would consider passing, yes.

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: Sorry kid. Even if I wanted to play harder, this knee won't let me.

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: I'm not just talking about you playing point guard... I'm talking about you teaching us... Monix could not be less interested.

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: Monix, you know more about basketball than any man who's ever set foot in Flint. Monix drinks, not into it...

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: All I'm saying is, instead of getting so pissed off at us all the time, why not just show us what the Hell you're talking about? Coach us a little. I mean, we can't get any worse.

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: And why should I give a shit about the Tropics?

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: I know you. You've got all that basketball shit stored up in your head. I know you're dying to pass it down to somebody. Why not us?

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: What about Jackie? He's the coach.

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: Jackie's got his hands full, trying to sell tickets. He's obsessed. (looking up, re: TV)

dialogues.speaker: ECU
dialogues.text: ON TV: The Tropics are performing a video not unlike 'The Super Bowl shuffle.' Each member takes a turn rapping, dancing around wooden palm trees with a smile.

dialogues.speaker: ALL THE TROPICS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (rapping badly) We are the Tropics hooping crew, running and gunning and dunking on you -- But we're not here to talk no trash, we're just here to do the Tropical Mash -- This is the worst video ever made. All the guys boogie ar until Clarence steps forward, taking focus...

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (rapping badly) I'm Johnny Johnson and I got the moves -- If you try and stop me, I'll just get smooth --

dialogues.speaker: KONG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (rapping badly) My name is Kong and I ain't five feet -- But I get more ass than a toilet seat --

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE MOON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This is my team, so get to know them -- If you get near the lane I'll yank your scrotum --

dialogues.speaker: ALL THE TROPICS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: -- We are the Tropics hooping crew, running and gunning and dunking too -- We're not here to talk no trash, we're just here to do the Tropical Mash -- The ball girls trot out and boogie with them.

dialogues.speaker: BALL GIRLS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: -- They're not here to talk no trash -- they're just here to do the Tropical Mash --

dialogues.speaker: CUT BACK TO
dialogues.text: MONIX CAN'T BELIEVE HIS EYES. Either can the bartender. M ignores Clarence.

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: (to the bartender) Two more Johnny Walkers.

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: So that's the way it's going to be? Monix doesn't answer, he just drinks. Clarence gets the h and walks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monix looks like shit, laying on the couch, as if he hasn moved for days. Apparently he's been drinking and smoking but not much else. KNOCK KNOCK. Someone's at the door. REVEAL: LYNN lets herself in. Monix is so depressed, he is non-plused.

dialogues.speaker: LYNN
dialogues.text: Looking good Monix.

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: Thanks. You too.

dialogues.speaker: LYNN
dialogues.text: Ms. Quincy told me the Tropics asked you to coach them.

dialogues.speaker: ECU
dialogues.text: Lynn is draining Monix's knee. It looks painful.

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: I know what it takes to be a real team, Lynn.

dialogues.speaker: LYNN
dialogues.text: (re: his knee) Stay still. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that's the reason you won't coach them?

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: It doesn't matter. The truth is, I hate basketball right now.

dialogues.speaker: LYNN
dialogues.text: Do you really hate basketball? Or do you hate yourself?

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: Why would I hate myself?

dialogues.speaker: LYNN
dialogues.text: Well, for one, you cheated on me.

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: You hate me for that. Not me. Lynn just stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: Okay, maybe I hate myself a little.

dialogues.speaker: LYNN
dialogues.text: You don't wear the ring around your neck anymore. (no response) Where is it?

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: I rode the bench through the playoffs, Lynn.

dialogues.speaker: LYNN
dialogues.text: Monix, that was greatest moment of your career. And you look back on it like some kind of embarrassment.

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: Riding the bench was the greatest moment of my career?

dialogues.speaker: LYNN
dialogues.text: You did more than ride the bench, Monix.

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: What else did I do?

dialogues.speaker: LYNN
dialogues.text: Every practice, you took your team to the limit. I know you did. I was the one draining this stupid knee of yours every night. The Celtics were practicing against you, Monix. And when you ran that scout team, you were running Milwaukee's offense better than their first stringers ever could. Lynn continues the business of disposing fluid into the toilet and preparing another syringe.

dialogues.speaker: LYNN
dialogues.text: By game time, your team knew where Milwaukee was going to be before their own players did. The Celtics made the right adjustments to win that series. And those adjustments came from you.

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: So, I should be proud of running the scout team?

dialogues.speaker: LYNN
dialogues.text: Dave Cowens put that ring in the palm of your hand. And he told you to wear it with pride, because you were a champion. And he meant it too.

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: He was being a nice guy. The bench is the bench.

dialogues.speaker: LYNN
dialogues.text: Your whole life, you've bitched about people playing selfish. It takes a team to win, right?

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: LYNN
dialogues.text: But when you're on the team, your effort doesn't count? Is that it? (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you weren't on the Celtics that year, would they have won it?

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: Watch that needle.

dialogues.speaker: LYNN
dialogues.text: Answer me. Would they have won?

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: LYNN
dialogues.text: Yes you do. You know. Monix looks away for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: MONIX
dialogues.text: Why are you doing this? What does any of this matter, anyway?

dialogues.speaker: LYNN
dialogues.text: What's it matter? You're drinking yourself to death! (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
